column337: -class="sortbottom" ! Programming language ! Default base index ! Specifiable index type[13] ! Specifiable base index ! Bound check ! Multidimensional ! Dynamically-sized ! Vectorized operations
column338: } Vectorized array operations Some compiled languages such as Ada and Fortran  and some scripting languages such as IDL  MATLAB  and S-Lang  have native support for vectorized operations on arrays. For example  to perform an element by element sum of two arrays  {{Mono
column341: c}}  it is only necessary to write     c = a + b

column1: In addition to support for vectorized arithmetic and relational operations  these languages also vectorize common mathematical functions such as sine. For example  if {{Mono
column2: x}} is an array  then     y = sin (x)
y}} whose elements are sine of the corresponding elements of the array {{Mono
column3: x}}. Vectorized index operations are also supported. As an example      even = x(2::2);

column1: is how one would use Fortran to create arrays from the even and odd entries of an array. Another common use of vectorized indices is a filtering operation. Consider a clipping operation of a sine wave where amplitudes larger than 0.5 are to be set to 0.5. Using S-Lang  this can be done by     y = sin(x);
Mathematical matrix operations Language/ Library Create Determinant Transpose Element Column Row Eigenvalues APL {{Mono
